story:
Spring into Action for St John Ambulance 

Jamie Douglas' Charity Event

Help us to raise money for St John Ambulance

Can you help us raise money for an amazing charity that helps save people's lives?

St John Ambulance is the charity that steps forward in the moments that matter to save lives and keep communities safe. They provide first aid services for communities and for emergency support. 

Did you know that they have supported the NHS during the covid-19 pandemic? They have supported with emergency calls and with the rollout of the vaccines. True heroes! 

As well as this, they also provide training to companies, authorities, and to members of the public. (Including myself having recently joined the St John's Cadets) 

I joined St John Ambulance Cadets to help make a positive impact and to help people. My interest started when we were coming back from visiting my Grandad and I happened to see a St John Ambulance. I questioned what it was and my dad told me it was a St John Ambulance. I was very interested to know about it. This is when we discovered that they do Cadet training. I thought, "Sign me up!"

All of St John Ambulance's charitable work is entirely funded by donations which is why we have decided to plan an event and raise money that will contribute to help support communities and help save people's lives. 

When I put the St John Cadet uniform on, I will help make a difference. Can you help me make that difference by taking part and/or donating to this amazing charity?

Charity Event - Treadmillathon

Date: Sunday 11th April 2021

Time: 11:00am- 16:00pm 

Location: Thompson Close, Mickleover (Outside no.31)

Our aim is to accomplish walking/running a marathon distance on a treadmill. We would like this to be a team effort with people having designated slots and taking turns to keep the treadmill consistently going (bar a minute or two to sanitize in between people's run to ensure Covid safety measures)

We will have cakes and refreshments available in which a small donation would go along the way to put towards St John Ambulance's Spring into Action appeal. (If you would like to donate cakes that would be fantastic!)

Put your walking/running shoes on and 'Spring into Action' to help us raise money for the St John heroes! Let's achieve the marathon goal together... We need you! 

Please contact Laura Douglas/ Jamie and/or Sarah Holmes and we can make a plan to keep the treadmill moving all day to achieve our marathon target. Spring is the season of new beginnings for all and together, we can do this!

If you would just like to wander up for refreshments and make donations, you are more than welcome :) Alternatively, if you are not available and wish to donate to this fantastic cause, please donate via this Just Giving page.

So this April, 'Spring into Action' for St John Ambulance and support our volunteers as they continue to step forward to give vital support to those in need across the country.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Kier Group has selected the British Heart Foundation, the biggest independent funder of cardiovascular research in the UK, as its new corporate charity partner. The two-year partnership will help in the charitys aim of increasing awareness of cardiovascular disease, raise £250,000 for vital research in to heart and circulatory conditions as well as train 1,500 Kier colleagues in the lifesaving first aid, CPR.

The British Heart Foundation is funding life saving research to help end heartbreak for the seven million people in the UK living with cardiovascular disease. For over 50 years it has pioneered research that has transformed the lives of people living with heart and circulatory conditions and has been pivotal to offering vital treatments that are changing the fight against heart disease.

story:
Anyone who knows me and sees me day to will know just how much I love chocolate. So this month I have given it up to help raise money for British Heart Foundation.

There research has helped both myself when my heart decided to start running at 240bpm and being diagnosed with Wolff parkinson white syndrome and also my friends gorgeous girl who had open heart surgery before she was one year old.

It's been a tough couple of weeks, especially when the hormones kick in but I'm still chocolate free this March and keeping going to help raise donations for BHF.

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. eventName: National Day of Reflection - Raising money for Marie Curie
story:
Chestnut Nursery Schools is supporting Marie Curie as part of its 
National Day of Reflection on 23rd March!

This will be an opportunity to reflect on the challenging year that has passed, support one another, and hope for a brighter future. Throughout March, Chestnut Nursery Schools will be taking part in a number of activities (including a sponsored Daffodil Doddle!), to raise funds for Marie Curie.

Here are some of the things the Marie Curie Foundation have said about the fundraiser -

"As a charity we have created a fantastic fundraising campaign for March, the Daffodil Doddle, which we hope everyone can be a part of.  It’s a really fantastic way to help keep your children active outdoors, whilst supporting a great cause too!

During the difficult last year our Nurses, hospices and telephone support line have been here through it all, day and night, 7 days a week, caring for people with and without Coronavirus.  We never stopped.  And right now, more people need us than ever before."

TV presenter Hamza Yassin is encouraging nurseries across the UK to take part in the Daffodil Doddle - 

"Now more than ever, it is so important to get children moving and out in the fresh air.  A daily walk is proven to improve the physical fitness, health and well-being of children.  By taking part in Marie Curie’s Daffodil Doddle, children will not only get all the physical benefits of the walk itself, they will also be raising money for terminally ill patients and their families which will develop their sense of accomplishment and community."

You can find out more information on the Marie Curie website - https://www.mariecurie.org.uk/get-involved/day-of-reflection

charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
On 2nd December 2020, we were given the devastating news that my Dad - John - had terminal cancer. There had been signs that something wasn’t quite right for several months prior to this diagnosis but it had never crossed any of our minds that the prognosis would be so devastating.

Due to John’s declining physical abilities, there were no treatment options available and so very quickly we had to come to terms with the fact that this situation was going to have the saddest conclusion. 

My mum and I were both recovering from COVID-19 at the time but we put everything else to one side and became full-time carers to my Dad. He gradually needed help with all daily tasks and slowly began to do less and eat less. 

A few weeks into the New Year, we came to a stage where we realised we needed some help and that is when the team at Marie Curie came into our lives. Every day they came to see my Dad, to talk to him, wash him and assess his medical needs. He laughed and joked with them most days, but his jovial and comedic personality slowly waned as his energy levels depleted. In some way, the man I called my Dad had already disappeared but we showed him our love every day and did our most to make him comfortable.

14 weeks after the diagnosis, on 10th March 2021, my Dad restfully fell to sleep for the last time, surrounded by love and peace.

If it hadn’t have been for those daily visits from the Marie Curie nurses then I don’t know what we would have done. Their input was completely invaluable, and we are still benefitting from their support even though my Dad is no longer with us. 

During our time with Marie Curie, I’ve learnt that around 90% of their staff are volunteers. However, it costs over £19,000 a year for one nurse and £13,000 a year for one Healthcare Assistant, in order to provide the care that is required. Because the charity relies on donations and fundraising, it’s staggering to realise that around 110,000 people every year in the UK do not have the end of life care that is needed. This is so sad and makes me even more thankful that this care and support was made available to us as a family at the very time that we all so desperately needed it.

We would therefore like to ask you to make a donation to Marie Curie, if you can. There is absolutely no pressure to do so though and we appreciate that times are very uncertain at the moment and that finances may be tight. However, if you are able to donate something, whether big or small, it will be gratefully received.
